bboxes.raw_text:
NEW YORK-Cassius Clay, the
talkative heavyweight boxing
champion. is scheduled to reap
pear before the Army induction
inspectors. He repeatedly failed
the mental portion of previous
examination.


Clay saidhe had taken the Army
test at Coral Gables. Florida,
ian. "a, but would offer no fur
Their statements.


He said he plans a world trip
and he intends to spend time in
Nigeria and other African coun-
tries.


Clay added he plans to buy a
100000 home in New York.

Clay to Face


More Druft Tests

COLUMBUS, O. - The NAACP
has recently started an intensive
program to ban discrimination
in housing as part Of its 10
year effort to end de facto seq
regation in the public schools.


In addition to working for a
city ordinance in this area and
a state law on open occupancy,
the Association has strongly
urged the Community Relations
Commission to recommend to the
Mayor that he issue an executive
order banning discrimination In
housing.


In a summary statement on
branch efforts to desegregate the
city schools, Rev. Phale D.Hale,
president Of the branch, reviewed
the steps taken by the NAACP
over the past ten years.


Citing the problem of the lack
of communications between pu-
pills, teachers and parents, Mr..
Hale praised the program
launched by the School Board and
Administration last year for an
in-service training institute for
human relations.


In addition to this, however,
he urged a strong look at the
counseling program in the
schools to bring the service cup
to date in terms Of present day
opportunities opening up to Ne
groes."

LOS ANGELES Three Negro
real estate brokers have filed suit
against the Southwest Realty
Board, charging the board acted
maliciously and arbitrarily in ex-
Guiding them from membership.


The brokers', Robert Spivey,
Jr., Bill Turner and rryCrane.
have attempted to join the South
west Board which is comprised
of 700 white brokers. Within the
Southwest's area are nearly 500
Negro brokers who have never
been able to join or participate
in the lucrative southwest null
tiple listing system.

NEW YORK > Herman Mccoy,
81, estranged husband Of actress
Claudia Mcneil. claims he did
not beat her or misuse her
$4,000 worth of savings.


Miss Mcneil, veteran actress
of Broadway and movies, said he
had beaten her, caused her to be
penniless and he had locked her
out of the house when she was
clad only In nightgown.


Mccoy said he was the injured
party because Miss Mcneil al
ways struck him first. He said
she had cut his lip and he had
suffered black eyes.


He is a waiter and owns a
beauty shop where Miss Mcneil
said he spent most other SIS. 900.


Mccoy countered saying she
was broke when he married her
and that she had less than l S cents
and owed two months rent when
they we're married.


Miss Mcneil was the mother
in "a Raisin in the Sum-, an
award winning Broadway play by
Lorraine Hansberry.

EAST ORANGE. NJ. Will
liam Stubs, a Negro was chosen
by an Essex County Republican
screening committee to run for
Congress in New Jerseys 18th
district.


Andrew C. Axtell, county Re-
publican chairman, said that if
Stubbs wins the April primary
he will be the first Negro con-
gressional candidate of a ma ior
party in New Jersey.

Negro May Run
For Congress


In New Jersey

Sandra Hollins, II, senior at
Yuma High School, lives at Isl
N. 18th Ave., in Yuma, Arizona.


A member of YHS Varsity band
for four years, she is section
leader in band. Her grade aver
age is IL.


She is a member ofLatin Club,
Tyres Club, Future Business
Leaders of America, Anchor Club
Warden's Club, National Honor
Society, Student Council, Girls
League and Senior Class Play.
"a.


She was sophomore class
treasurer, junior class secre-
tary, Past treasurer of FBLA,
Yuma High School Chapter, I'm
mediate State Secretary of Ari-
IONA FBLA Future BUSINESS
Leaders of America), immediate
student body secretary. Yuma
High School, Zonta Club Girl of
the Month for March, 1864.


She was a delegate to Girls
State. 1868; appointed city man
ager at Girls State yucca City,.
and elected as Outstanding Citi-
zen of the City.


Sandra was elected Miss Per-
sonality, l963-64 and nominated
for Homecoming Queen.


She serves as secretary to Ari-
zona's Republican National Com
mitteewoman, Mrs. F C. Braden.

COMPTON. Calf. = Compton
City Council voted to change the
name of Alabama Avenue to Evers
Avenue last week.


Ceremonies were held as Mrs.
Medgar Evers, widow Of the slain
NAACP leaders helped place the
new street sign in place.

Judge Irwin Cantor, Maricopa
County Superior Court, has re-
ceived a fellowship from the
W. K. Kellogg Foundation to at
tend the National College of State
Trial Judges this summer in
Boulder. Colorado. The only state
Judge selected. Judge Cantor will
join fellow trial judges from
all over the United States in
a four-week seminar July 6-3l
at the University Of Colorado
School Of Law. The seminar will
be the inaugural session of an
annual study conference at the
University under the auspices
of the American Bar Associa-
tion.


Judge Cantor was appointed a
Judge of the Superior Court in
January, 1868, by Governor Paul
Fannin. Admitted to the Arizona
Bar in l949, Judge Cantor has
also served as assistant attorney
general, assistant city attorney
and city prosecutor for the City
of Phoenix, and was In private
practice as a partner in the law
firm of Cantor and Ely prior to
taking the bench.
